choices.text: It's a battle between bacteria and neutrophil
It is chromatin with antibacterial enzymes

questions.text: All of the following are true about Neutrophil Traps (NET) except
questions.solution:
(Choice C) Mitochondrial DNA is seen - False

Because classical NETs are primarily composed of nuclear chromatin, not mitochondrial DNA.

Incorrect choices explanation :

(Choice A) Seen in sepsis - True

NETs are commonly observed in sepsis as part of the body's immune response to severe infections. They help trap and kill bacteria but can also contribute to excessive inflammation and tissue damage.

(Choice B) It's a battle between bacteria and neutrophil - True

NETs are part of the ongoing battle between neutrophils and pathogens. They serve to immobilize and neutralize bacteria, fungi, and other pathogens.

(Choice D) It is chromatin with antibacterial enzymes - True

NETs consist of chromatin (DNA and histones) along with various antimicrobial enzymes such as elastase, myeloperoxidase (MPO), and cathepsin G, which help in neutralizing pathogens.

Key takeaway :

Classical NETs are primarily composed of nuclear chromatin, not mitochondrial DNA.

choices.text: Fresh and old intra alveolar hemorrhage
Pulmonary artery hypertrophy with increased resistance

questions.text: Post mortem changes seen in lung after death of a patient from Covid after a week are?
questions.solution:
COVID-19 primarily affects the lungs, leading to severe acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) in critically ill patients. The post-mortem histopathological findings in the lungs of COVID-19 patients typically reflect extensive inflammatory damage, vascular injury, and fibrosis.

After one week of infection and subsequent death, the lungs exhibit features of progressive lung damage, including diffuse alveolar damage (DAD), vascular thrombosis, and hemorrhage.

Correct Answer: (Choice A) Fresh and old intra-alveolar hemorrhage

  • COVID-19-induced severe inflammation causes vascular damage and capillary leakage, leading to intra-alveolar hemorrhage.
  • Histopathology often shows both fresh (recent) and old (resolving) hemorrhage, reflecting different stages of lung injury.
  • Thrombosis and microvascular damage contribute to the hemorrhagic changes.
  • This finding is characteristic of severe viral pneumonia and ARDS in COVID-19 patients.

Incorrect choices explanation:

  • (Choice B) Thick layer of fibrin - Partially true, but not the best answer → Fibrin deposition in alveoli is seen in ARDS, but it is not the most defining feature of post-mortem COVID lungs. Instead, hyaline membrane formation and alveolar hemorrhage are more prominent.
  • (Choice C) Perivascular cuffing - False → Perivascular cuffing (lymphocytic infiltrates around blood vessels) is characteristic of chronic inflammatory diseases like tuberculosis or chronic viral infections (e.g., HIV, CMV). → COVID-19 primarily causes diffuse alveolar damage (DAD) with endothelial injury, thrombosis, and hemorrhage rather than perivascular lymphocytic infiltrates.
  • (Choice D) Pulmonary artery hypertrophy with increased resistance - False → Pulmonary artery hypertrophy is seen in chronic pulmonary hypertension, but COVID-19 causes acute vascular injury rather than long-term remodeling of the pulmonary arteries. → The vascular changes in COVID-19 include thrombosis, endothelial damage, and microvascular injury, not hypertrophy.

Key takeaway:

The most characteristic post-mortem lung changes in a patient who died from COVID-19 after one week are fresh and old intra-alveolar hemorrhage, making (A) the correct answer.

Reference: https://doi.org/10.5858/arpa.2020-0491-SA

questions.text: A known case of hemorrhoids presented with fatigue after 6 months of blood loss Hb-9gm%, MCV 60, MCHC 27, MCH 23, RBC 5.2 million cells/mm3. Peripheral smear is given below, what is the next investigation you will do?
questions.solution:
In Given data Mentzer index: MCV/RBC: 60/5.2 = 11.5 with target cells. Which is suggestive of Thalassemia Minor. For confirmation of Thal. Minor HbA2 is a Gold standard investigation. HbA2 in thal minor is 4 % to 8 %.


Incorrect Choices Explanation

Choice A: Serum Folate

  • Folate deficiency leads to macrocytic anemia (high MCV, not low).
  • The given MCV (60) is low, ruling out folate deficiency.

Choice B: Serum Ferritin

  • Ferritin is measured for iron deficiency anemia (IDA), which also presents with low MCV.
  • However, RBC count in IDA is low, while in thalassemia minor, RBC count is normal or high.
  • Since the MentzerIndex is <13, IDA is unlikely.

Choice D: Homocysteine

  • Homocysteine is elevated in B12 and folate deficiencies, which cause macrocytic anemia (high MCV).
  • The patient has microcytic anemia, making this test unnecessary.

Key takeaway : Mentzer index <13 (thirteen less anemia) - Thalassemia Minor

>13 - Iron deficiency anemia.

choices.text: Increasing telomere length is proportional to aging
Telomere mutation is associated with increased aging
Decreased telomere length is associated with aging
Increased telomerase activity is associated with aging

questions.text: True statement of telomerase theory of aging
questions.solution:
The telomerase theory of aging suggests that the progressive shortening of telomeres plays a significant role in the aging process. Telomeres are protective caps at the ends of chromosomes that prevent DNA damage. With each cell division, telomeres shorten, eventually leading to cellular senescence, apoptosis, or genomic instability-all of which contribute to aging.

Correct Answer: (Choice C) Decreased telomere length is associated with aging.

Incorrect choices explanation:

  • (Choice A) Increasing telomere length is proportional to aging - False → If telomere length were increasing, it would delay aging rather than accelerate it. However, in normal somatic cells, telomeres shorten with age, not lengthen.
  • (Choice B) Telomere mutation is associated with increased aging -False → While mutations in telomerase genes can accelerate aging (as seen in telomeropathies like aplastic anemia).
  • (Choice D) Increased telomerase activity is associated with aging - False → Increased telomerase activity is actually seen in cancer cells, allowing them to divide indefinitely (immortality). In normal cells, higher telomerase activity would delay aging, not promote it.

Key Takeaway:

The most accurate and widely accepted explanation for aging based on the telomerase theory is that decreased telomere length is associated with aging.

questions.text: Which of the following will increase life span/delay the aging process
questions.solution:
Among the given options, the most scientifically proven method to increase lifespan and delay the aging process is caloric restriction (CR) by 30%, making (Choice C) Decrease calorie by 30% the correct answer.

Why is (Choice C) the correct answer?

Caloric restriction (CR) without malnutrition has been extensively studied in multiple organisms and has shown increased lifespan and delayed aging.

CR reduces oxidative stress, lowers metabolic rate, enhances insulin sensitivity, and activates longevity-associated pathways like sirtuins (SIRT1), AMPK, and autophagy.

In primate studies, CR has been associated with lower incidence of age-related diseases, including cancer, diabetes, and cardiovascular disease.

Mechanism: CR reduces mTOR signaling (which is associated with aging) and enhances stress resistance at the cellular level.

Incorrect choice explanation;

(Choice A) Regular exercise - Incorrect

→While exercise improves overall health, reduces age-related diseases, and improves quality of life, its direct effect on maximal lifespan extension is less proven compared to caloric restriction.

(Choice B) Decrease stress - Incorrect

→Chronic stress accelerates aging by increasing cortisol levels, leading to inflammation and cellular damage. Reducing stress improves healthspan but does not significantly extend lifespan in the way caloric restriction does.

(Choice D) Pharmacological intervention by taking PPIs - Incorrect

→Proton Pump Inhibitors (PPIs) are used for acid reflux and ulcers, but long-term PPI use has been linked to increased risk of kidney disease, fractures, and infections, which could negatively impact longevity rather than extending lifespan.

Key takeaway:

While exercise and stress reduction improve healthspan, caloric restriction (CR) by 30% has the strongest evidence for delaying aging and increasing lifespan

questions.text: A patient has got raised LDH, bilirubin and hemoglobinuria. What is most likely associated with this
questions.solution:
Clues in the Question:

Elevated Lactate Dehydrogenase (LDH): A marker of cell breakdown, commonly increased in hemolysis.

Raised Bilirubin (Indirect): Suggests red blood cell (RBC) destruction, leading to increased unconjugated bilirubin.

Hemoglobinuria: Indicates intravascular hemolysis, where free hemoglobin is released into the bloodstream and excreted in urine.

Why is the correct answer (Choice B) Mechanical 2nd heart valve?

Mechanical heart valves can cause traumatic destruction of RBCs as they pass through the prosthetic valve, leading to mechanical hemolysis.

Shear stress on RBCs results in their fragmentation, producing schistocytes (helmet cells) on a peripheral smear.

This condition is known as prosthetic valve-associated hemolysis and can lead to hemolytic anemia.

Incorrect choices explanation:

(Choice A) Splenomegaly - Incorrect

  • Splenomegaly is associated with extravascular hemolysis (e.g., hereditary spherocytosis), where RBCs are destroyed in the spleen. It does not typically cause hemoglobinuria, as RBCs are removed before they rupture in circulation.

(Choice C) Increased HbA2- Incorrect

  • Increased HbA2 is a hallmark of β-thalassemia trait, which presents with microcytic anemia, not hemolysis with hemoglobinuria.

(Choice D) Goitre - Incorrect

  • A goiter is related to thyroid disease and has no direct link to hemolysis or hemoglobinuria.

Key takeaway:

Patients present with elevated LDH, bilirubin, and hemoglobinuria, which are indicative of intravascular hemolysis.

choices.text: Decrease glucose utilization by neoplastic cells
Useful to make intermediated for survival
Yields more energy in the form of increased ATP production

questions.text: Neoplastic cells utilize Warburg, metabolism for which of the following reasons
questions.solution:
The Warburg effect prioritizes biosynthesis over ATP generation, providing essential precursors for nucleotides, amino acids, and lipids, which are necessary for rapid cell proliferation.

Although glycolysis is less efficient in terms of ATP yield compared to oxidative phosphorylation, it provides metabolic intermediates that are essential for cell survival and replication.

Incorrect choices explanation:

(Choice A) Decrease glucose utilization by neoplastic cells - False

  • Cancer cells actually increase glucose uptake and metabolism through glycolysis, leading to high glucose consumption (basis of PET scans).

(Choice C) Yields more energy in the form of increased ATP production - False

  • Glycolysis generates less ATP compared to oxidative phosphorylation (only 2 ATP per glucose vs. ~36 ATP). The Warburg effect is not about energy maximization but about supplying biosynthetic precursors.

(Choice D) Makes the cancer cells immortal - False

  • While metabolic adaptations contribute to cancer survival, immortality in cancer cells is primarily driven by telomerase activation and genetic alterations, not the Warburg effect alone.

Key takeaway

The Warburg effect describes how neoplastic (cancer) cells preferentially utilize glycolysis for energy production even in the presence of oxygen (aerobic glycolysis). This metabolic adaptation allows cancer cells to generate essential biosynthetic intermediates needed for rapid growth and survival

questions.text: Identify the given structure
questions.solution:
The Islets of Langerhans are clusters of endocrine cells dispersed within the exocrine pancreas.These clusters appear as lighter-staining regions compared to the surrounding darker-staining pancreatic acini.

Incorrect choices explanation:

(Choice A): Lymph Node- capsule, lymphoid follicles in cortex, medulla.

(Choice B): Glomeruli- Tuft of capillaries surrounded by Bowman's capsule, seen in the renal cortex.

(Choice C): Demilune - demilunes are half-moon shaped formations of serous cells in some salivary glands.

The histology confirms it is an Islet of Langerhans, making this incorrect.

Key takeaway: The Islets of Langerhans are clusters of endocrine cells dispersed within the exocrine pancreas

questions.text: A 56-year-old male patient complains of dragging pain in the abdomen. On examination, there is massive splenomegaly, there is high TLC, high platelets and high Hb. Peripheral as shown in the image. The patient had 2-3% blasts, metamyelocytes - 7%. What is the translocation seen in this condition?
questions.solution:
Here all the symptoms are in favor of Chronic Myeloid leukemia (CML). Which show (A): t (9:22)

Incorrect choices explanation:

(Choice B): t (8:22)- Burkitt's

(Choice C): t (15:17) - Acute Pro myelocytic Leukemia.(APML)

(Choice D): t (8:14) - B cell malignancy (B-ALL, Burkitt's lymphoma.

Key Takeaway: Massive splenomegaly causes: 3M: Malaria, Myelofibrosis, CML

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient underwent a cystoscopy which showed multiple yellow white plaque in the bladder. Histopathology shows infiltrated lamina propria. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The patient's cystoscopy findings of multiple yellow-white plaques in the bladder and histopathology showing infiltration into the lamina propria are characteristic of Malakoplakia, a rare chronic granulomatous inflammatory condition of the bladder.

Key Features of Malakoplakia:

  • Etiology: Chronic E. coli or other bacterial infections.
  • Pathogenesis: Defective macrophage phagocytosis leads to accumulation of undigested bacterial products.
  • Histology:
    • Michaelis-Gutmann bodies(basophilic laminated inclusions due to calcium and iron deposits in lysosomes).
  • Cystoscopic Appearance:
    • Multiple yellow-white plaques in the bladder mucosa.
  • (Choice A) Malakoplakia → TRUE (Correct Answer)
    • Classic cystoscopic and histologic features(yellow-white plaques, lamina propria infiltration, Michaelis-Gutmann bodies).

Incorrect choices explanation:

  1. (Choice B) Interstitial Cystitis → FALSE
    • Chronic bladder pain syndrome (Hunner's ulcers, no bacterial infection).
    • No yellow-white plaques or histological macrophage infiltration.
  2. (Choice C) Acute Cystitis (Follicular Cystitis) → FALSE
    • Follicular cystitisshows lymphoid follicles in the bladder wall, not yellow-white plaques.
  3. (Choice D) Chronic Cystitis (Polypoidal Growth) → FALSE
    • Polypoid cystitis presents with mucosal polyps, not plaques.

Key takeway:

The cystoscopic appearance of yellow-white plaques. The macrophages have abundant granular cytoplasm due to phagosomes stuffed with particulate and membranous debris of bacterial origin, which are believed to accumulate due to defective phagolysosome function. In addition, laminated mineralized concretions resulting from deposition of calcium in enlarged lysosomes, known as Michaelis-Gutmann bodies, are typically present within the macrophages.

questions.text: A 6-year-old male patient presents with abdominal pain. He was admitted with a history of chest infection 2 years back. Pallor is present on examination. HPLC shows raised HbF and HbS. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The 6-year-old male presents with abdominal pain, pallor, and a history of chest infection (likely acute chest syndrome). HPLC findings show increased HbF and HbS, which is diagnostic for sickle cell anemia (SCA).

(Choice B) Sickle Cell Anemia → TRUE (Correct Answer)

  • Presence of HbS and HbF on HPLC confirms the diagnosis.
  • Symptoms align with classic manifestations of sickle cell disease.

Incorrect choices explanation:

  • (Choice A) Beta Thalassemia → FALSE
    • HPLC in β-thalassemia majorshows increased HbF and absent/low HbA, but does not show HbS.
    • Patients with β-thalassemia do not have vaso-occlusive crises.
  • (Choice C) Paroxysmal Nocturnal Hemoglobinuria (PNH) → FALSE
    • PNH is a complement-mediated hemolytic disorderwith pancytopenia and venous thrombosis, diagnosed by flow cytometry (CD55/CD59 deficiency), not HPLC.
  • (Choice D) Autoimmune Hemolytic Anemia (AIHA) → FALSE
    • AIHA is Coombs-positive hemolysis, with spherocytes on blood smear, but no HbS on HPLC.

Key takeaway:

Given the clinical presentation of abdominal pain, history of chest infection, pallor, and characteristic HPLC findings (HbS, elevated HbF, absent HbA), the most likely diagnosis is Sickle Cell Anemia (SCA).

questions.text: A 10-year-old child with no pain in the bone shows sclerotic changes. Peripheral smear is as shown below. Most common organism implanted in osteomyelitis of the patient is?
questions.solution:
The question describes a 10-year-old child with sclerotic bone changes and an abnormal peripheral smear, suggesting an underlying hematological disorder. The most common association in such cases is sickle cell disease (SCD).

Key Considerations:

  1. Osteomyelitis in Sickle Cell Disease (SCD):
    • Salmonella species is the most common cause of osteomyelitis in patients with sickle cell disease.
    • Pathogenesis: Vaso-occlusion leads to bone infarcts, creating a hypoxic environment that favors Salmonella over Staphylococcus aureus.
    • Other common pathogens: coli, Klebsiella, and other Gram-negative organisms.
  2. Sclerotic Bone Changes in a Child:
    • In sickle cell disease, repeated infarctions lead to sclerosis and osteonecrosis.
    • The patient's painless presentation suggests a chronic process rather than acute infection.
  3. Peripheral Smear Findings in Sickle Cell Disease:
    • Sickle cells, target cells, Howell-Jolly bodies(seen in autosplenectomy).

(Choice C) Salmonella → TRUE (Correct Answer)

  • Most frequent cause of osteomyelitis in sickle cell patients due to bone infarcts and altered immune function.

Incorrect choices explanation:

  • (Choice A) Staph aureus → FALSE
    • Most common cause of osteomyelitis in general population.
  • (Choice B) Streptococcus → FALSE
    • Group A Streptococcus (Streptococcus pyogenes) can cause osteomyelitis but is not the most common cause in SCD patients.
  • (Choice D) Pseudomonas→ FALSE: Pseudomonas is associated with osteomyelitis in IV drug users and puncture wounds to the foot, not in sickle cell disease.

Key takeaway:

The most common organism causing osteomyelitis in a child with sickle cell disease is Salmonella.

questions.text: Which of the following mutation results in the formation of a stop codon
questions.solution:
A nonsense mutation is a type of point mutation where a single nucleotide change results in the formation of a premature stop codon (UAA, UAG, UGA). This leads to early termination of protein synthesis.

(Choice B) Nonsense Mutation → TRUE (Correct Answer)

  • Creates a premature stop codon (UAA, UAG, UGA).

Incorrect choices explanation:

  • (Choice A) Missense Mutation → FALSE
    • A single nucleotide change results in a different amino acid substitution in the protein.
    • Example: Sickle Cell Anemia (Glu → Val in β-globin gene, HBB mutation).
    • Does not create a stop codon.
  • (Choice C) Frameshift Mutation → FALSE
    • Insertion or deletion of nucleotides (not in multiples of 3) shifts the reading frame.
    • Example: Tay-Sachs Disease, Cystic Fibrosis.
  • (Choice D) Silent Mutation → FALSE
    • A single nucleotide change that does not alter the amino acid sequence due to codon redundancy (wobble hypothesis).
    • No impact on protein function.

Key takeaway:

A nonsense mutation directly introduces a stop codon, terminating translation prematurely.

questions.text: Which of the following disorders is inherited in an autosomal recessive manner:
questions.solution:
Cystic fibrosis (CF) is an autosomal recessive disorder caused by mutations in the CFTR gene (Cystic Fibrosis Transmembrane Conductance Regulator) located on chromosome 7.

(Choice A) Cystic fibrosis → TRUE (Correct Answer)

  • Autosomal recessive inheritance

Incorrect choices explanation:

  • (Choice B) Huntington's disease → FALSE
    • Autosomal dominant disorder caused by CAG trinucleotide repeat expansion in the HTT gene on chromosome 4.
  • (Choice C) Achondroplasia → FALSE
    • Autosomal dominant disorder caused by a mutation in the FGFR3 gene.
  • (Choice D) Treacher Collins syndrome → FALSE
    • Autosomal dominant disorder

Key takeaway:

Among the given options, only Cystic Fibrosis follows an autosomal recessive inheritance pattern.

questions.text: A 27-year-old male patient with road traffic accident develops dyspnea, petechial rash and unconsciousness after 2 days. What is the most likely cause?
questions.solution:
The patient is a 27-year-old male who suffered a road traffic accident (RTA) and developed dyspnea, petechial rash, and unconsciousness after 2 days. This classic triad is highly suggestive of Fat Embolism Syndrome (FES).

  • (Choice B) Fat embolism → TRUE (Correct Answer)
    • Classic triad: dyspnea, petechiae, neurological symptoms.
    • Delayed onset(24-72 hours after trauma).

Incorrect choices explanation:

  • (Choice A) Air embolism → FALSE
    • Usually occurs after trauma to veins, scuba diving (decompression sickness), or iatrogenic causes (central line insertion, surgery).
    • Presents immediately with cardiovascular collapse, not after 2 days.
  • (Choice C) Thromboembolism → FALSE
    • Presents as pulmonary embolism (PE) with sudden dyspnea, pleuritic chest pain, and tachycardia.
    • No petechial rash is seen.
  • (Choice D) SCC (Squamous Cell Carcinoma) → FALSE
    • Not related to the clinical scenario. SCC is a chronic malignancy, not an acute post-trauma event.

Key takeaway:

Given the history of trauma, delayed onset (2 days), respiratory distress, petechial rash, and neurological symptoms, the most likely diagnosis is Fat Embolism Syndrome (FES).

questions.text: A 12-year-old male patient presents with bloating, steatorrhoea, HLAdQ2 defect. Which of the following is the best treatment?
questions.solution:
The patient is a 12-year-old male presenting with bloating, steatorrhea (fatty stools), and an HLA-DQ2 defect, which are characteristic features of Celiac Disease (Gluten-Sensitive Enteropathy).

  • (Choice C) Low gluten diet → TRUE (Correct Answer)
    • Gluten-free diet is the main treatment, leading to intestinal healing, symptom resolution, and prevention of complications (e.g., osteoporosis, lymphoma).

Incorrect choices explanation:

  • (Choice A) Low lactose → FALSE
    • Secondary lactose intolerance can occur due to villous atrophy in celiac disease, but eliminating lactose alone does not treat the disease.
  • (Choice B) High lactose → FALSE
    • A high-lactose diet can worsen symptoms in individuals with lactose intolerance secondary to mucosal damage.
  • (Choice D) Non-selective proteinuria → FALSE
    • Non-selective proteinuria is seen in glomerular diseases like FSGS and membranous nephropathy, which are unrelated to celiac disease.

Since the best treatment for Celiac Disease is a strict gluten-free diet, the correct answer is (Choice C) Low gluten diet.

Key takeaway:

  • Pathophysiology of Celiac disease: Autoimmune response triggered by gluten ingestion in genetically predisposed individuals (HLA-DQ2 or HLA-DQ8).
  • Symptoms: Chronic diarrhea, bloating, steatorrhea, weight loss, failure to thrive (in children), iron deficiency anemia, and dermatitis herpetiformis.
  • Histology: Villous atrophy, crypt hyperplasia, and intraepithelial lymphocytosis in the small intestine.

questions.text: Histopathological picture of an ulcerated nodule at the tip of nose measuring 0.3 cm shown. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The tip of the nose is a common site for Basal Cell Carcinoma (BCC)

(Choice B) BCC (Correct Answer) → TRUE

Histology shows basaloid tumor cells, peripheral palisading, and clefting.

Incorrect choices explanation:

(Choice A) Keratoacanthoma → FALSE

Rapidly growing dome-shaped lesion with central keratin-filled crater.

Histologically shows keratin plug and well-differentiated squamous cells, not palisading basaloid cells.

(Choice C) Melanoma → FALSE

Typically presents as an irregular pigmented lesion with variable colors (brown, black, red).

Histologically, atypical melanocytes infiltrate the dermis and epidermis.

(Choice D) SCC (Squamous Cell Carcinoma) → FALSE

Typically presents as a scaly, ulcerated lesion with an indurated base.

Histology shows keratin pearls and intercellular bridges.

Key takeaway:

A small ulcerated nodule on the tip of the nose with histological features of peripheral palisading basaloid cells and clefting artifact strongly suggests Basal Cell Carcinoma (BCC)

choices.text: Light microscopy shows effacement of podocytes

questions.text: A 10-year-old male patient with edema, anasarca. A diagnosis of minimal change disease was made. Which of the following is true?
questions.solution:
(Choice A) Responds well to steroids: This is the hallmark of MCD. It's often dramatically responsive to corticosteroid treatment. This is a key factor in its diagnosis and management.

Incorrect choices explanation:

(Choice B) Light microscopy shows effacement of podocytes: While true, this is seen on electron microscopy, not light microscopy. Light microscopy usually appears normal in MCD.

(Choice C) Common in adults: MCD is much more common in children, with a peak incidence between 2 and 6 years old. It's relatively uncommon in adults.

(Choice D) Non-selective proteinuria: MCD is characterized by selective proteinuria, meaning it primarily leaks albumin (the smallest protein) rather than larger proteins.

Therefore, the most accurate statement about Minimal Change Disease is (Choice A) Responds well to steroids.

Key takeaway: Minimal change disease is a steroid-responsive glomerular disease seen primarily in children, with normal light microscopy and effacement of podocyte foot processes on electron microscopy. It causes selective proteinuria.

choices.text: Nuclear features are characteristic of this tumour

questions.text: A middle-aged male presents with painless, slow growing neck swelling, lymph node biopsy was positive. The biopsy of the lymph node was given below. Which of these statements is not true.
questions.solution:
Painless, slow-growing neck swelling: This suggests a chronic process, likely a neoplasm (tumor).

Lymph node biopsy positive: This confirms malignancy within the lymph node.

The image provided shows a classic picture of Papillary Thyroid Carcinoma.

(Choice D) FNAC is not diagnostic:

Fine-needle aspiration cytology (FNAC) is a very useful and often diagnostic tool for papillary thyroid carcinoma. The characteristic nuclear features can often be identified in FNAC samples.

Therefore, this statement is false

Incorrect choices explanation:

(Choice A) Nuclear features are characteristic of this tumour:

The image provided indicates papillary thyroid carcinoma, which is known for its distinctive nuclear features, including:

"Orphan Annie" eye nuclei (clear nuclei with central clearing).

Nuclear grooves.

Nuclear pseudoinclusions.

Therefore, this statement is true.

(Choice B) Spreads through lymphatics:

Papillary thyroid carcinoma is known to spread primarily through the lymphatic system. This is a common characteristic of this type of cancer.

Therefore, this statement is true.

(Choice C) Excellent prognosis:

Papillary thyroid carcinoma generally has an excellent prognosis.Therefore, this statement is true.

Key takeaway: The statement that is not true is (Choice D) FNAC is not diagnostic. FNAC is, in fact, often diagnostic for papillary thyroid carcinoma.
